evidence.text: Congressional District No. 6 has been a majority black district since 1992 and is represented by Congressman James Clyburn, lost significant population as a result of the state becoming increasingly urban with many rural communities within the district experiencing a loss in population.
evidence.source_document: Findings Of Fact And Conclusions Of Law

add_extracted.value: Congressional District No. 6 has been a majority black district since 1992 and is represented by Congressman James Clyburn, lost significant population as a result of the state becoming increasingly urban with many rural communities within the district experiencing a loss in population.

evidence.text: The overall African American percentage of the total South Carolina population decreased between 2010 and 2020 from 28.2% to 25.9%, primarily as a result of predominantly white migration into the state over the prior decade.
evidence.source_document: Findings Of Fact And Conclusions Of Law

add_extracted.value: The overall African American percentage of the total South Carolina population decreased between 2010 and 2020 from 28.2% to 25.9%, primarily as a result of predominantly white migration into the state over the prior decade.

evidence.text: Congressional District No. 1 had an excess in population of 87,689 (11.99%).
evidence.source_document: Findings Of Fact And Conclusions Of Law

add_extracted.value: Congressional District No. 1 had an excess in population of 87,689 (11.99%).

evidence.text: Congressional District No. 6 had a deficiency of 84,741 (11.59%).
evidence.source_document: Findings Of Fact And Conclusions Of Law

add_extracted.value: Congressional District No. 6 had a deficiency of 84,741 (11.59%).

evidence.text: Berkeley County had a total population of 229,861 and an African American population of 54,440 (23.7%).
evidence.source_document: Findings Of Fact And Conclusions Of Law

add_extracted.value: Berkeley County had a total population of 229,861 and an African American population of 54,440 (23.7%).

evidence.text: Beaufort County had a population of 187,117 and an African American population of 29,105 (15.6%).

add_extracted.value: Beaufort County had a population of 187,117 and an African American population of 29,105 (15.6%).

evidence.text: Dorchester County had a population of 127,543 and an African American population of 27,076 (21.2%).

add_extracted.value: Dorchester County had a population of 127,543 and an African American population of 27,076 (21.2%).

evidence.text: When the populations of these three counties were combined, they totaled 544,521 of the district’s ideal population of 731,203 and had an African American percentage of 20.3%.
evidence.source_document: Findings Of Fact And Conclusions Of Law

add_extracted.value: When the populations of Berkeley, Beaufort, and Dorchester counties were combined, they totaled 544,521 of the district’s ideal population of 731,203 and had an African American percentage of 20.3%.

evidence.text: Charleston County had an African American population of 23.17%.
evidence.source_document: Findings Of Fact And Conclusions Of Law

add_extracted.value: Charleston County had an African American population of 23.17%.

evidence.text: Roberts moved 62% (30,243 of 48,706) of the African American residents formerly assigned to Congressional District No. 1 to District No. 6, leaving only 18,463 African Americans in the Charleston portion of Congressional District No. 1.
evidence.source_document: Findings Of Fact And Conclusions Of Law

add_extracted.value: Roberts moved 62% (30,243 of 48,706) of the African American residents formerly assigned to Congressional District No. 1 to District No. 6, leaving only 18,463 African Americans in the Charleston portion of Congressional District No. 1.

evidence.text: Roberts moved ten of the eleven VTDs with an African American population of 1,000 persons or greater out of Congressional District No. 1 to District No. 6, which included a move of over 11,300 African Americans from North Charleston and nearly 17,000 from the St. Andrews area.
evidence.source_document: Findings Of Fact And Conclusions Of Law

evidence.text: 44.  The Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution provides that states may not “deprive any person of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law.”
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested

add_extracted.value: Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment prohibits depriving any person of life, liberty, or property without due process of law.

evidence.text: 45.  The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment guarantees citizens the right to vote in state and federal elections and requires that state legislative districts be apportioned with substantially equal populations, giving each person equal representational access and each voter equal electoral opportunity.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested

add_extracted.value: Equal Protection Clause guarantees citizens the right to vote and requires state legislative districts to be apportioned with substantially equal populations.

evidence.text: South Carolina’s current legislative and U.S. Congressional districts are based on 2010 Census data, even though 2020 data is available.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, Three Judge Panel Requested

add_extracted.value: South Carolina's current legislative and U.S. Congressional districts are based on 2010 Census data, despite 2020 data availability.

evidence.text: After much delay, on January 26, 2022, Governor McMaster signed into law S. 865, which redistricted the South Carolina congressional districts for the next decade as Act 118.
evidence.source_document: Third Amended Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: On January 26, 2022, Governor McMaster signed into law S. 865, which redistricted the South Carolina congressional districts for the next decade as Act 118.

evidence.text: S. 865 is the latest iteration of South Carolina’s long pattern of official acts of redistricting.
evidence.source_document: Third Amended Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: S. 865 is the latest iteration of South Carolina’s long pattern of official acts of redistricting.

evidence.text: The Legislature used race as the predominant factor motivating its decisions to place a significant number of voters, like Mr. Scott, within or outside of the Challenged Congressional Districts.
evidence.source_document: Third Amended Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The Legislature used race as the predominant factor motivating its decisions to place a significant number of voters, like Mr. Scott, within or outside of the Challenged Congressional Districts.
